'''ABKO Properties''' was a [[joint venture]] between [[Wichita, Kansas]] [[real estate]] entrepreneur George Ablah and Wichita-based [[Koch Industries]] formed specifically to purchase Chrysler Realty Corporation in the late 1970s from a hard-pressed [[Lee Iacocca]]. Koch Industries is ranked 2 among the Forbes list of largest private companies. Chrysler Realty Corporation purchases, leases or options dealership facilities and then leases or subleases these facilities to Chrysler dealers. The name ABKO was derived from the first two letters of Ablah’s name and the first two letters of Charles Koch’s name, who is head of Koch Industries. At the time ABKO was formed, Chrysler was on the verge of bankruptcy.
==History==
ABKO purchased around 840 Chrysler [[Car dealerships in the USA|automotive dealership]] sites around the country controlled by Iacocca in 1979 for slightly over $100 million in cash. Not all the sites were owned by Chrysler Realty.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chrysler's Realty Sale May Be Overly Touted|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1979/09/16/chryslers-realty-sale-may-be-overly-touted/9ca2d3dc-7163-42ae-844c-7a0f35ee3037/|website=The Washington Post|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=4 May 2016}}</ref>
Under the leadership of Ablah and his team, Chrysler Realty president Ed Homer (for a brief time), executive vice president Corliss (Corky) Nelson of Koch,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10D10FF3B5C0C728CDDAB0894DA484D81|title=EXECUTIVES|date=1982-02-01|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2008-06-09}}</ref> acquisition/disposition specialists Wayne Delfino and Frank Mills, and attorney John Schippel, among others, ABKO set forth a strategy to diversify Chrysler Realty Corporation by way of liquidating non-performing Chrysler dealership properties by tax-free exchange and sale.
In 1983, Iacocca, assisted by a government bailout he organized, repurchased 446 of the dealerships in a measure aimed at strengthening the Chrysler dealer network. ABKO dissolved shortly thereafter.

{{more footnotes|date=June 2017}} [[Image:Fire_sprinkler_roof_mount_side_view.jpg|thumb|right|'''Suppression''': Sprinkler head. Heat causes the liquid in the bulb to expand, burst the glass and create an opening through which the water is released to extinguish fire.]] [[Image:Residential smoke detector.jpg|thumb|right|'''Detection''':A common, residential smoke detector sounds an alarm when smoke is detected, to initiate egress.]] '''Active fire protection''' ('''AFP''') is an integral part of [[fire protection]]. AFP is characterized by items and/or [[system]]s, which require a certain amount of motion and response in order to work, contrary to [[passive fire protection]].
==Categories of active fire protection== ===Fire suppression=== {{redirect|Extinguishing a fire|extinguishing coal fires|Coal seam fire#Extinguishing coal fires}} Fire can be controlled or extinguished, either manually (firefighting) or automatically. Manual control includes the use of a [[fire extinguisher]] or a [[Standpipe (firefighting)|standpipe]] system. Automatic control means can include a [[fire sprinkler system]], a gaseous clean agent, or firefighting foam system. Automatic suppression systems would usually be found in large commercial kitchens or other high-risk areas.
===Sprinkler systems===
Fire sprinkler systems are installed in all types of buildings, commercial and residential. They are usually located at ceiling level and are connected to a reliable water source, most commonly city water. A typical sprinkler system operates when heat at the site of a fire causes a glass component in the sprinkler head to fail, thereby releasing the water from the sprinkler head. This means that only the sprinkler head at the fire location operates – not all the sprinklers on a floor or in a building. Sprinkler systems help to reduce the growth of a fire, thereby increasing life safety and limiting structural damage.
==Fire detection==
Fire detection works using [[Smoke detector|smoke]] or [[Heat detector|heat]] sensors. These systems are very effective tool at alerting people in the immediate vicinity of where the fire is detected but [[building code|building regulations]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sans10400.co.za/fire-protection/|title=SANS10400 Building Regulations|publisher=}}</ref> require an integrated fire detection system. These system not only alerts people throughout the building by triggering the fire alarm but it can also summon emergency services. There are two types of systems available – addressable and conventional. Addressable systems monitor the specific location of each device (eg smoke detector, call point or sounder). It means in the event of a fire or other emergency you know exactly where the problem is. This saves precious time and helps the emergency services prevent the loss of life and serious damage. Conventional systems can only determine the problem is in a general area and thus are more suited for small sites.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://intellisec.co.za/fire-detection/|title=Fire Detection Systems|publisher=Intellisec}}</ref>
When the fire detection system is activated it can also send an alert to the local [[fire department]], broadcast a prerecorded warning message and unlock the buildings [[access control]] system.
==Hypoxic air fire prevention==
Fire can be prevented by hypoxic air. [[Hypoxic air fire prevention system]]s, also known as oxygen reduction systems are new automatic fire prevention systems that reduce permanently the oxygen concentration inside the protected volumes so that ignition or fire spreading cannot occur. Unlike traditional fire suppression systems that usually extinguish fire after it is detected, hypoxic air is able to prevent fires. At lower altitudes hypoxic air is safe to breathe for healthy individuals.
==Construction and maintenance== All AFP systems are required to be installed and maintained in accordance with strict guidelines in order to maintain compliance with the local [[building code]] and the fire code.
AFP works alongside [[passive fire protection|modern architectural designs and construction materials]] and fire safety education to prevent, retard, and suppress structural fires.

The '''Addis Ababa Agreement''', also known as the [[Addis Ababa]] Accord, was a set of compromises within a 1972 treaty that ended the [[First Sudanese Civil War]] (1955–1972) fighting in [[Sudan]]. The Addis Ababa accords were incorporated in the [[Constitution of Sudan]].
==Preliminaries and Negotiations== Direct Negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the [[Anyanya| Southern Sudan Liberation Movement (SSLM)]] in Addis Ababa were preceded in 1971 by a series of discussions through the intermediation of the [[All Africa Conference of Churches| All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC)]] and [[World Council of Churches| World Council of Churches (WCC)]]. In Addis Ababa, in 1972, [[Abel Alier]] led the delegation representing the Government of Sudan. [[Ezboni Mondiri]] led the delegation of the Southern Sudan Liberation Movement (SSLM).<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v9NIrNTedJkC&pg=PA188 |title=Eastern African history |first=Robert O. |last=Collins |publisher=Markus Wiener Publishers |year=1991 |ISBN=1-55876-016-4}}</ref> The negotiations were moderated by [[Burgess Carr]], who was then the Secretary General of the [[All Africa Conference of Churches]].<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Juba University |editor-first=Rift Valley Institute |title=We Have Lived Too Long to Be Deceived: South Sudanese discuss the lessons of historic peace agreements |url= http://riftvalley.net/publication/we-have-lived-too-long-be-deceived|location= London, UK |publisher=Rift Valley Institute |date=2015 |isbn=}}</ref>
==Results== The Agreement had the goal to address and appease concerns of the southern Sudan liberation and secession movement, as the First Sudanese Civil War grew costly in lives and resources to the northern Sudanese government and southern population. The Addis Ababa Agreement's establishment of the [[Southern Sudan Autonomous Region (1972–83)|Southern Sudan Autonomous Region]] gave a degree of [[autonomy]]. <ref>http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Sudan.html#Southern</ref> It meant South Sudan would no longer be divided into the three separate regions Al-Istiwāʾiyyah (Equatoria), Baḥr al-Ghazāl, and Aʿālī al-Nīl (Upper Nile). The region would run itself through a separate legislative and executive body. The soldiers of the Anya Nya would be integrated into the Sudanese army and police force. The Addis Ababa Agreement gave Nimeri popularity and prestige both within Sudan and outside of the country. <ref>https://www.britannica.com/place/Sudan/The-Addis-Ababa-Agreement#ref48975</ref>
A decade of relative peace followed, though the Addis Ababa Agreement failed to dispel the tensions that had originally caused civil war. The Addis Ababa Agreement proved to be only temporary respite. Resource infringements and marginalisation by the north led to increased unrest in the south starting in the late 1970s.
==Termination== In 1983 President [[Gaafar Nimeiry]] declared all Sudan an [[Islamic state]] under [[Shari'a]] law, including the non-Islamic majority southern region. The Southern Sudan Autonomous Region was abolished on 5 June 1983, ending the Addis Ababa Agreement. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pachodo.org/201010061749/Pachodo.org-English-Articles/history-of-southern-sudan-hoss.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716052232/http://www.pachodo.org/201010061749/Pachodo.org-English-Articles/history-of-southern-sudan-hoss.html |archivedate=2011-07-16 }}</ref> This initiated the [[Second Sudanese Civil War]] (1983–2005).

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Transgender sidebar}} A '''bathroom bill''' is the common name for legislation or a statute that defines access to [[public toilet]]s (restrooms)—by [[transgender]] individuals. Bathroom bills affect access to sex-segregated public facilities for an individual based on a determination of their sex as defined in some specific way—such as their sex as [[sex assignment|assigned at birth]], their sex as listed on their [[birth certificate]], or the sex that corresponds to their [[gender identity]].<ref name=vox>{{cite web | url=https://www.vox.com/2016/4/7/11381400/tennessee-transgender-bathroom-bill | title=Tennessee's anti-transgender bathroom bill, explained | work=Vox | date=April 7, 2016 | accessdate=April 7, 2016 | author=Lopez, German}}</ref> A bathroom bill can either be inclusive or exclusive of transgender individuals, depending on the aforementioned definition of their sex.
Critics of bills which exclude transgender individuals from restrooms which conform to their gender identity argue that they do not make public restrooms any safer for [[cisgender]] (non-transgender) people, and that they make public restrooms less safe for both transgender people and [[gender non-conforming]] cisgender people.<ref name="mic.com">{{cite web|url=https://mic.com/articles/114066/statistics-show-exactly-how-many-times-trans-people-have-attacked-you-in-bathrooms|first=Marcie|last=Bianco|title=Statistics Show Exactly How Many Times Trans People Have Attacked You in Bathrooms|date=April 2, 2016}}</ref><ref name="rolereboot">{{cite web|title=Stop Using Women's Safety to Justify Transphobia|url=http://www.rolereboot.org/culture-and-politics/details/2016-04-stop-using-womens-safety-justify-transphobia/|date=April 12, 2016|first=Linday|last=King-Miller}}</ref><ref name="patheos">{{cite web|url=http://www.patheos.com/blogs/friendlyatheist/2016/04/11/more-republican-politicians-than-trans-people-have-been-arrested-for-sex-acts-in-bathrooms/|title=More Republican Politicians Than Trans People Have Been Arrested For Sex Acts in Bathrooms|last=Firma|first=Terry|date=April 11, 2016}}</ref> Additionally, critics claim there have been no cases of a transgender person attacking a cisgender person in a public restroom,<ref name="mic.com" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Broverman|first1=Neal|title=Trump Supporter Broadcasts Live as She Chases Trans Woman Out of Bathroom|url=https://www.advocate.com/transgender/2018/5/17/trump-supporter-broadcasts-live-she-chases-trans-woman-out-bathroom|accessdate=18 May 2018|publisher=The Advocate|date=17 May 2018}}</ref> although there has been at least one isolated incident of voyeurism in a fitting room.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news|last1=Chokshi|first1=Miraj|title=Transgender Woman is Charged With Voyeurism at Target in Idaho|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/15/us/target-transgender-idaho-voyeurism.html?_r=2|accessdate=31 May 2017|work=NYT|publisher=New York Times|date=14 July 2014}}</ref> By comparison, a much larger percentage of transgender people have been verbally, physically, and sexually harassed or attacked by cisgender people in public facilities.<ref name="usts">{{cite web|url=http://www.transequality.org/sites/default/files/docs/USTS-Executive-Summary-FINAL.PDF|title=2015 U.S. Transgender Survey : Executive Summary|work=U.S. Transgender Survey|publisher=National Center for Transgender Equality|location=Washington}}.</ref> For these reasons the controversy over transgender bathroom access has been labeled a [[moral panic]]<ref name="psmag">{{cite web|url=https://psmag.com/magazine/how-social-bias-is-segregating-americas-bathrooms|title=Stalled Out: How Social Bias is Segregating America's Bathrooms|last=Wheeling|first=Kate|date=August 4, 2017}}</ref> and compared to the [[antisemitism|antisemitic]] [[blood libel]].<ref name="savage-blood-libel">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestranger.com/slog/archives/2015/02/09/florida-rep-wants-to-throw-trans-people-in-prison-for-using-public-toilets|last=Savage|first=Dan|work=The Stranger|date=February 9, 2015|title= Florida Representative Wants to Throw Trans People in Prison for Using Public Toilets}}</ref>
Proponents say such legislation is necessary to maintain privacy, protect what they claim to be an innate sense of modesty held by most cisgender people, prevent voyeurism, assault, molestation, and rape,<ref name="Guardian-2015">{{cite web |title=Florida anti-transgender bathroom bill moves a step closer to passing |last1=Kasperkevic |first1=Jana |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/mar/17/florida-anti-transgender-bathroom-bill |date=17 March 2015 |website=The Guardian |publisher= Guardian News and Media Ltd. |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=11 July 2017 |quote= }}</ref> and retain psychological comfort.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://time.com/4701658/texas-senate-bathroom-bill-sb6-transgender/ | title=Texas Senate Approves Controversial Bathroom Bill After Five-Hour Debate | work=Time | date=14 March 2017 | accessdate=27 June 2017 | author=Steinmetz, Katy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/443153/transgender-bathrooms-conservative-defense-transgender-rights | title=A Conservative Defense of Transgender Rights | work=National Review | date=17 December 2016 | accessdate=27 June 2017 | author=Gelernter, Josh}}</ref>
One bathroom bill, the [[Public Facilities Privacy & Security Act]] in [[North Carolina]], was approved as a law in 2016, although portions of the measure were later repealed in 2017 as part of a compromise between the Democratic governor and Republican-controlled Legislature.
Also in 2016, guidance was issued by the U.S. Departments of Justice and Education stating that schools which receive federal money must treat a student's gender identity as their sex (for example, in regard to bathrooms).<ref name="huffingtonpost2">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-transgender_us_58ac4fe8e4b0a855d1d9d278 |title=Trump Administration Rescinds Protections For Transgender Students | HuffPost |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date=2017-02-22 |accessdate=2018-01-18}}</ref> However, this policy was revoked in 2017.<ref name="huffingtonpost2"/>

==Opposition==
Critics of bathroom bills have argued that they place transgender people in danger without making cisgender people any safer and that they even make things more dangerous for gender non-conforming cisgender people.<ref name="mic.com" /><ref name="rolereboot" /> The UCLA's [[Williams Institute on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity Law and Public Policy|Williams Institute]] has tracked prevalence of crimes in bathrooms since the passage of various protections for the transgender population and has found that there has been no significant change in the number of crimes.<ref name="auto" /> Marcie Bianco, writing for [[Mic (media company)|Mic]], pointed out that there is not a single documented case of a transgender person attacking a cisgender person in a public restroom.<ref name="mic.com" /> Writing for [[Patheos]], Terry Firma argued that there have been more Republican politicians arrested for sex acts in bathrooms than transgender people.<ref name="patheos" /> The controversy has been labeled a [[moral panic]],<ref name="psmag" /> and [[Dan Savage]] went so far as to call it an "anti-trans [[blood libel]]".<ref name="savage-blood-libel" />
According to the largest U.S. survey of transgender people ever undertaken, carried out by the [[National Center for Transgender Equality]] (NCTE) in 2015 with 27,715 respondents, one percent of respondents reported being sexually assaulted in a public restroom for being transgender. Twelve percent reported being verbally harassed in a public restroom, and another one percent reported being non-sexually physically assaulted for being transgender. Nine percent reported being denied the right to use a public restroom consistent with their gender.<ref name="usts" /> The NCTE acknowledges that in its report that this survey was undertaken before any bathroom bills had been passed or were in the news.<ref name="usts" />
== By country ==
===Canada===
In Canada, the [[New Democratic Party]] (NDP) has introduced several bills that tried to include gender identity and [[gender expression]] among the characteristics protected from discrimination and eligible to be considered in sentencing [[Hate crime|crimes motivated by hate]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Garrison introduces bill to protect transgender rights |last= Nease |first=Kristy |newspaper= Goldstream Gazette |location= [[Langford, British Columbia]] |date=September 22, 2011 |page=1}}</ref> These bills were frequently referred to as "bathroom bills" by their critics as they would have allowed transgender individuals to use the public facilities corresponding to their gender identity.
In 2009, NDP [[Member of Parliament (Canada)|MP]] [[Bill Siksay]] introduced Bill C-389 to the [[40th Canadian Parliament|40th Parliament]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Bill C-389 (Historical)|url=https://openparliament.ca/bills/40-2/C-389/|website=openparliament.ca|accessdate=April 21, 2016}}</ref> The bill was passed by the [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]] in 2011 but was defeated by the [[Senate of Canada|Senate]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ibbitson|first1=John|title=Transgendered-rights bill headed for defeat in Tory-held Senate|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawa-notebook/transgendered-rights-bill-headed-for-defeat-in-tory-held-senate/article611671/|accessdate=April 21, 2016|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=February 10, 2011}}</ref>
Bill C-279, introduced to the [[41st Canadian Parliament|41st Parliament]] in 2011 by NDP MP [[Randall Garrison]], was passed and sent to the Senate in March 2013.<ref>{{cite web |title=Commons approves transgender rights bill |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2013/03/20/pol-transgender-rights-bill-approved.html |date=March 20, 2013 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=March 26, 2013}}</ref> In 2015, Senator [[Don Plett]] introduced three amendments to the bill, one of which exempted public washrooms and changerooms from the bill's protections.<ref>{{cite web |title=Transgender rights bill gutted by 'transphobic' Senate amendment |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/transgender-rights-bill-gutted-by-transphobic-senate-amendment-1.2975024 |date=February 27, 2005 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=April 21, 2016 |author= McGregor, Janyce}}</ref> The bill was also ultimately defeated in the Senate.
Garrison re-introduced the bill to the [[42nd Canadian Parliament|42nd Parliament]] as Bill C-204.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Page|first1=Jillian|title=NDP re-introduces transgender rights bill in the House of Commons|url=http://montrealgazette.com/news/national/ndp-re-introduces-transgender-rights-bill-in-the-house-of-commons|accessdate=April 21, 2016|work=[[Montreal Gazette]]|language=en-US}}</ref>
[[Bill C-16]], a similar bill to the NDP bills, was intruded on May 17, 2016 by Federal Minister of Justice [[Jody Wilson-Raybould]] to the [[42nd Canadian Parliament|42nd Parliament]]. The bill passed the legislative process in the House of Commons and the Senate, and became law upon receiving [[Royal Assent]] on June 19, 2017, coming into force immediately.<ref>[http://www.parl.gc.ca/LEGISInfo/Home.aspx?language=E&ParliamentSession=42-1 LegisInfo (42nd Parliament, 1st Session).]</ref><ref>[http://www.parl.gc.ca/LegisInfo/BillDetails.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&billId=8269852 LEGISinfo - House Government Bill C-16 (42-1)]</ref><ref name="cbc-16jun2017">{{cite news|last1=Tasker|first1=John Paul|title=Canada enacts protections for transgender community|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/transgender-rights-bill-senate-1.4163823|accessdate=June 16, 2017|newspaper=[[CBC News]]|date=June 16, 2017}}</ref>
===United States=== [[File:2018.03.24 March for Our Lives, Washington, DC USA 4504 (27124276608).jpg|thumb|right|"Trans bathroooms never killed anyone!" sign at [[March for Our Lives]] (2018)]] {{See also|Gender identity under Title IX}} In a landmark 2013 case, the Colorado Civil Rights Division ruled in favor of 6-year-old transgender student [[Growing Up Coy|Coy Mathis]] to use the girls' bathroom at her elementary school. It was the first ruling of its kind in the United States and one of the first high-profile transgender rights cases, garnering huge amounts of media attention.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/05/15/477954537/when-a-transgender-person-uses-a-public-bathroom-who-is-at-risk|title=When A Transgender Person Uses A Public Bathroom, Who Is At Risk?|website=NPR.org|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref>
In May 2016, the [[United States Department of Justice]] and the [[United States Department of Education]] released a joint guidance on the application of [[Title IX]] protections to transgender students.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/us-departments-justice-and-education-release-joint-guidance-help-schools-ensure-civil-rights|title=U.S. Departments of Justice and Education Release Joint Guidance to Help Schools Ensure the Civil Rights of Transgender Students|website=www.justice.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref> The guidance stated that for the purpose of Title IX, the Department of Justice and the Department of Education treat a student's [[gender identity]] as their sex. The guidance was followed by a formal [[Dear colleague letter (United States)|"Dear Colleague" letter]] on May 13.<ref>{{cite letter |author1=U.S. Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division |author2=U.S. Department of Education, Office for Civil Rights |recipient=Colleague |subject=Dear Colleague Letter on Transgender Students |date=13 May 2016 |url=https://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ocr/letters/colleague-201605-title-ix-transgender.pdf |accessdate=6 September 2017}}</ref>
In October 2016, the [[SCOTUS|U.S. Supreme Court]] agreed to take up the [[Gender identity under Title IX#G.G. v. Gloucester County School Board|case of Gavin Grimm]], a [[trans man|transgender male]] student who was barred from using the boys' bathrooms at [[Gloucester High School (Virginia)|his high school]] in [[Gloucester County, Virginia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Supreme Court to rule in Gloucester transgender case|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JztylepmWIM|website=WAVY TV 10|accessdate=October 29, 2016|date=October 28, 2016}}</ref> The [[U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit]] had previously ruled that Grimm could use these restrooms, but the Supreme Court stayed that decision in August.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Robert Barnes|author2=Moriah Balingit|title=Supreme Court takes up school bathroom rules for transgender students|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/supreme-court-takes-up-school-bathroom-rules-for-transgender-students/2016/10/28/0eece4ea-917f-11e6-a6a3-d50061aa9fae_story.html|website=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=October 29, 2016|date=October 28, 2016}}</ref>
====Alaska==== [[Anchorage, Alaska]] prohibited discrimination based on gender identity in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.adn.com/anchorage/article/anchorage-assembly-debates-lgbt-rights-law/2015/09/30/|title=Anchorage Assembly passes LGBT rights law|last=Kelly|first=Devin|date=September 29, 2015|work=Anchorage Daily News|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> In 2017, Alaska Family Action proposed a [[direct initiative]] bathroom bill that would have overturned protections for transgender individuals. [[Municipality of Anchorage Proposition 1, 2018|Proposition 1]] would have made it legal for "any employer, public accommodation, or other person to establish and enforce sex-specific standards or policies concerning access to intimate facilities such as locker rooms, showers, changing rooms, and restrooms." The measure defines the term sex as "An individual's immutable biological condition of being male or female, as objectively determined by anatomy and genetics at the time of birth."<ref>[https://www.muni.org/Departments/Assembly/Clerk/Elections/2018%20Election/2017-2_Updated_Redacted%20Final.pdf 2017-2]</ref> Voters rejected the bill in April 2018.<ref>https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/alaskans-vote-no-on-anti-transgender-bathroom-bill/ar-AAvAO7o?li=BBnb7Kz&OCID=ansmsnnews11</ref>
====Alabama==== A bathroom bill was introduced in [[Alabama]] on February 7, 2017 by state Senator [[Phil Williams (Alabama senator)|Phil Williams]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://legiscan.com/AL/text/SB1/2017|title=Bill Text - AL SB1 |accessdate=2017-02-25}}</ref> The bill, if passed, would require attendants to be present in mixed-gender public bathrooms to ensure that no crimes are committed there.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.al.com/news/index.ssf/2017/01/alabama_bathroom_bill_targets.html |title=Alabama bathroom bill targets transgender right |last=Harress |first=Christopher |website=AL.com |publication-date=7 January 2017 |access-date=25 February 2017}}</ref>
====Arizona==== A 2013 proposed amendment to Arizona bill S.B.1432 would have allowed police to demand identification from anyone suspected of using the 'wrong' public bathrooms or showers, meaning the facilities assigned to the sex not matching the sex on their birth certificate. If found guilty, a person would have been subject to up to 6 months in jail and a $2500 fine under a disorderly conduct charge.<ref name="Arizona S.B. 1432">{{cite web|last1=Kavanagh|first1=John|title=PROPOSED HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES AMENDMENTS TO S.B. 1432|url=http://www.azleg.gov/legtext/51leg/1r/proposed/h.1432-se-kavanagh.doc.htm|website=Arizona Legislature}}</ref><ref name="Mic Arizona Bill">{{cite news|last1=Strupp|first1=Julie|title=Arizona Transgender Bathroom Bill: Let Us Pee Without Showing ID|url=http://mic.com/articles/30882/arizona-transgender-bathroom-bill-let-us-pee-without-showing-id|publisher=Mic.com|date=March 24, 2013}}</ref> The proposal was withdrawn by its sponsor, [[John Kavanagh (American politician)|John Kavanagh]].<ref name="mj">{{cite web | url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2015/03/transgender-bathroom-discrimination-bills | title=Get Ready for the Conservative Assault on Where Transgender Americans Pee | work=Mother Jones | date=March 9, 2015 | accessdate=April 7, 2016 | author=Brodey, Sam}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/politics/articles/20130605kavanagh-bathroom-bill-shelved.html | title=Arizona transgender bathroom bill won't move | work=Arizona Republic | date=June 5, 2013 | accessdate=April 8, 2016 | author=Gardiner, Dustin}}</ref>
====California==== AB 1266, also known as the "School Success and Opportunity Act," was introduced by Assemblyman Tom Ammiano on February 22, 2013. It requires that pupils be permitted to participate in sex-segregated school programs, activities, and use facilities consistent with their gender identity, without respect to the gender listed in a pupil's records. AB 1266 was approved by Governor Brown on August 12, 2013.
In September 2016, California Governor [[Jerry Brown]] signed a bathroom bill that mandates single-occupancy public bathrooms be gender-neutral in order to enable easier access for transgender people. The law went into effect on March 1, 2017.<ref>[http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/California-Gender-Neutral-Restroom-Bill-Becomes-Law-395340641.html California Gender-Neutral Restroom Bill Becomes Law]. ''NBC Bay Area''. Retrieved December 4, 2016.</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Katy |last=Steinmetz |url=http://time.com/4514068/california-single-occupancy-all-gender/ |title=Single Occupancy Bathrooms in California Must Be for 'All Genders' |work=[[Time Magazine]] |date= September 29, 2016 |accessdate=December 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201520160AB1732|title=Bill Text - AB-1732 Single-user restrooms. |accessdate=2017-02-09}}</ref>
====Colorado==== In Colorado, in February 2015, a bill died in committee that proposed banning transgender people from using changing rooms of their gender identity.<ref name="Colorado bathroom bill">{{cite news|last1=Marcus|first1=Peter|title=Transgender bill shot down|url=http://www.durangoherald.com/article/20150204/NEWS01/150209830/Transgender-bill-shot-down-|agency=Durango Herald|publisher=Durango Herald}}</ref> This bill would have prevented discrimination lawsuits against facility managers who chose to deny entry into facilities to transgender people.
====Florida==== A bathroom bill was introduced in [[Florida]] in the spring of 2015 as H.B. 583 by Representative [[Frank Artiles]].<ref name=nytgg/><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/humaninterest/wave-of-bathroom-bills-in-south-has-floridas-transgender-community-worried/2274226|title=Wave of bathroom bills has Florida's transgender community worried it's next|website=Tampa Bay Times|language=en-us|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref> Artiles complained that, under laws protecting transgender use of restrooms, "A man such as myself can walk into the bathroom at LA Fitness while women are taking showers, changing, and simply walk in there." His bill would have made it illegal for transgender people to use bathrooms corresponding to their gender identity in restaurants, workplaces, or schools. The consequences would be up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bixby|first1=Scott|title=This Lawmaker Wants to Make It Illegal for Transgender People to Use Bathrooms|url=https://mic.com/articles/110314/this-lawmaker-wants-to-make-it-illegal-for-trans-people-to-use-bathrooms|accessdate=18 May 2018|publisher=Mic|date=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="HB 583 Florida">{{cite web|title=HB 583|url=http://www.myfloridahouse.gov/Sections/Bills/billsdetail.aspx?BillId=53629|website=Florida House of Representatives}}</ref><ref name='Florida lawmaker criminalize public restroom "safety"'>{{cite web|last1=Ford|first1=Zack|title=Florida Lawmaker Wants To Criminalize Transgender Bathroom Use For 'Public Safety'|url=http://thinkprogress.org/lgbt/2015/02/09/3620887/florida-transgender-bathroom-discrimination/|publisher=Think Progress}}</ref> Proponents claimed that the bill was designed to prevent "assault, battery, molestation, rape, voyeurism, and exhibitionism".<ref name="Guardian-2015" /> Opponents claimed that the only purpose was to be "discriminatory" and to "criminalize [transgender people] for simply going about their daily lives".<ref name="az-2015">{{cite web |title=Transgender bathroom bill maybe down the drain |last1=Flowers |first1=Garin |url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/florida/2015/04/15/transgender-bathroom-bill-maybe-down-the-drain/25838689/ |date=15 April 2015 |website=az central |publisher=Arizona Republic Media |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=11 July 2015 |quote= }}</ref> The bill went through two House committees, but did not pass.<ref>{{Cite act|title=Single-Sex Public Facilities|type=Bill|number=CS/CS/HB583|date=February 4, 2015|url=http://www.myfloridahouse.gov/Sections/Bills/billsdetail.aspx?BillId=53629|accessdate=March 4, 2017}}</ref> There were no further bathroom bills filed in the Florida state legislature in 2015 or 2016, but organizations like [[Equality Florida]] said in 2017 that they were preparing for the possibility of future bills.<ref name=":0" />
====Kentucky==== A 2015 proposal in Kentucky would have allowed students to sue their school if they encountered transgender students using the bathroom corresponding to the gender with which they identify. It would have allowed transgender students instead to request special accommodations, including access to single-stall or faculty restrooms.<ref name="Kentucky bathroom bill news">{{cite news|last1=Wynn|first1=Mike|title=Transgender Bathroom Bill Passes Ky Senate|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/politics/ky-legislature/2015/02/27/transgender-bathroom-bill-passes-kentucky-senate/24130083/|date=March 1, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Kentucky bathroom bill senate voting record">{{cite web|title=SB 76: 2015 Regular Session. Friday, February 27th, 2015|url=http://www.lrc.ky.gov/record/15RS/SB76/vote_history.pdf|website=Kentucky Legislature}}</ref> On February 27, 2015, the bill S.B. 76 passed in the [[Kentucky Senate]],<ref>{{cite web |first=Mike |last=Wynn |url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/politics/ky-legislature/2015/02/27/transgender-bathroom-bill-passes-kentucky-senate/24130083/ |title=Transgender bathroom bill passes Ky Senate |newspaper=[[Louisville Courier-Journal]] |date=March 1, 2015 |accessdate=November 30, 2016}}</ref> but it did not pass the Kentucky House.<ref name=nytgg>The Editorial Board, [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/27/opinion/for-transgender-americans-legal-battles-over-restrooms.html For Transgender Americans, Legal Battles Over Restrooms], ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 27, 2015</ref>
====Massachusetts==== Massachusetts prohibited discrimination in sex-segregated facilities based on gender identity in 2016. Voters were asked whether to repeal this law when [[Question 3 (2018, Massachusetts)|Question 3]] appeared on the ballot on November 6, 2018. This was the first time such a question was put to voters at the state level. The law was upheld by approximately 1.76 million votes for and 834,000 votes against.<ref>[http://www.wbur.org/news/2018/11/06/question-3-transgender-ballot-yes-wins Creamer, Lisa; "Mass. Votes 'Yes' On Question 3 To Keep Law Protecting Transgender People In Public Accommodations"], [[WBUR]], November 6, 2018</ref>
====Minnesota==== A bathroom bill was introduced in [[Minnesota]] in 2016.<ref name=nytgg/><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.twincities.com/2016/04/12/privacy-vs-discrimination-legislature-debates-transgender-bathroom-bill/ |title='Privacy' vs. 'discrimination': Legislature debates transgender bathroom bill |last=Montgomery |first=David |website=[[TwinCities.com]] |publication-date=April 12, 2016}}</ref>
====Missouri==== Two bathroom bills were introduced in [[Missouri]] in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/future-unknown-missouris-bathroom-bill-k-12-advocates-say-districts-already-handling#stream/0 |title=Future unknown for Missouri's 'bathroom bill'; K-12 advocates say districts 'already handling this' |last=Griffin |first=Marhsall |website=St Louis Public Radio |publication-date=February 18, 2017}}</ref>
====Nevada==== On March 19, 2015, [[Victoria Dooling]], a [[Nevada]] state representative, proposed a bathroom bill that would apply to public schoolchildren in the state.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/4/1/transgender-bathroom-bills-are-a-statewide-trend.html | title=The growing trend of transgender 'bathroom bully' bills | work=Al Jazeera America | date=April 1, 2015 | accessdate=April 7, 2016 | author=Taylor, Marisa}}</ref> It later died in committee.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://legiscan.com/NV/bill/AB375/2015 | title=Nevada Assembly Bill 375 | work=Legiscan | accessdate=April 8, 2016}}</ref>
====North Carolina==== [[File:2016 River Parade 5 (28425722173).jpg|thumb|right|Waterborne protest opposing HB-2]] {{Main|Public Facilities Privacy & Security Act}} On March 23, 2016, North Carolina Governor [[Pat McCrory]] (R) signed into law the [[Public Facilities Privacy & Security Act]] (commonly known as House Bill 2). The law states that in government buildings, individuals (such as students at state-operated schools) may only use restrooms and changing facilities that correspond to the sex identified on their birth certificates. Transgender persons born in North Carolina can obtain modified birth certificates on which their sex is different than what was originally [[sex assignment|identified at the time of their birth]], but only if they have undergone [[sex reassignment surgery]].<ref name=NCTL>{{cite web |last=Shoichet |first=Catherine E. |url= http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/03/us/north-carolina-gender-bathrooms-law-opposing-views/|title=North Carolina transgender law: Is it discriminatory? |website=[[CNN]] |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=November 30, 2016}}</ref> For those born in other places, the ability to change the sex listed on a birth certificate is governed by their place of birth (which may have substantially different requirements, and in some cases may not allow such changes).<ref name=NCTL/>
The bill also overturns an [[Anti-LGBT discrimination in the United States|LGBT anti-discrimination]] ordinance that had been passed by [[Charlotte, North Carolina]], prevents local governments in the state from enacting similar ordinances, and prevents cities from raising their [[minimum wage]]s higher than that of the state.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/03/north-carolina-lgbt-discrimination-transgender-bathrooms/475125/ |title=North Carolina Overturns LGBT-Discrimination Bans |work=[[The Atlantic]] | date=March 24, 2016 | accessdate=April 7, 2016 | author=Graham, David A.}}</ref>
On August 26, 2016, a [[U.S. District Court]] judge granted a preliminary injunction, preventing the [[University of North Carolina]] from enforcing the restroom provisions of the bill.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Geidner|first1=Chris|title=Federal Judge Orders UNC Not To Enforce 'Bathroom Bill' Provision Of Anti-LGBT Law|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/chrisgeidner/federal-judge-orders-unc-not-to-enforce-bathroom-bill-provis|website=[[Buzzfeed]]|accessdate=August 26, 2016|date=August 26, 2016}}</ref>
On March 30, 2017, the legislature partially repealed House Bill 2, removing the restrictions on restroom use by transgender individuals. The compromise agreement was criticized by both LGBT rights groups and conservatives.<ref name="nytimes-30mar2017">{{cite news|last1=Fausset|first1=Richard|title=Bathroom Law Repeal Leaves Few Pleased in North Carolina|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/30/us/north-carolina-senate-acts-to-repeal-restrictive-bathroom-law.html|accessdate=March 30, 2017|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 30, 2017}}</ref>
====South Carolina==== In April 2016, Sen. Lee Bright brought a bill (S. 1203) to the [[South Carolina]] Senate, that was essentially the same as North Carolina's HB2.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wistv.com/story/31659358/sen-lee-bright-introduces-bathroom-bill-to-state-senate|title=Sen. Lee Bright introduces 'bathroom bill' to SC Senate|last=Turnage|first=Jeremy|date=April 6, 2016|website=WISTV|archive-url=http://www.wistv.com/story/31659358/sen-lee-bright-introduces-bathroom-bill-to-state-senate|archive-date=April 6, 2016|dead-url=|access-date=December 7, 2017}}</ref> The bill would block local governments from passing anti-discriminatory ordinances such as: the use of public bathrooms by gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender individuals.<ref name=":1" /> Senator Bright's bill would maintain that public bathrooms be used in accordance to "biological sex." <ref name=":1" /> An online poll taken from a news site stated that 75% of voters did not think the bill was necessary.<ref name=":1" /> The legislation failed to meet the crossover deadline for bills to pass from one legislative chamber to the other.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.thestate.com/news/politics-government/politics-columns-blogs/the-buzz/article74310252.html |title=SC transgender bathroom bill dead |last=Self |first=Jamie |website=The State |publication-date=April 27, 2016}}</ref>
In December 2016, a similar bill was introduced by Rep. Steven Wayne Long in the [[South Carolina]] house. (H. 3012)<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.wistv.com/story/34097308/freshman-sc-lawmaker-files-bathroom-bill-as-nc-works-to-repeal-theirs |title=Freshman state lawmaker files 'bathroom bill' as NC works to repeal theirs |last=Turnage |first=Jeremy |website=wistv |publication-date=December 20, 2016}}</ref>
====South Dakota==== {{main|South Dakota House Bill 1008}} On February 16, 2016, the [[South Dakota]] Senate voted 20-15 to approve [[South Dakota House Bill 1008|a bathroom bill]] that, had it passed, would have been the first in the country to require public schoolchildren to use facilities that match the sex they were assigned at birth.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://time.com/4220345/south-dakota-bathroom-bill-religious-freedom/ | title=South Dakota Could Pass 'Bathroom Bill' Affecting Transgender Students | work=Time | date=February 16, 2016 | accessdate=April 7, 2016 | author=Steinmetz, Katy}}</ref> On March 1, 2016, the governor of South Dakota, [[Dennis Daugaard]], vetoed the bill.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/01/us/south-dakota-transgender-bathroom-bill/ | title=South Dakota governor vetoes transgender bathroom bill | work=CNN | date=March 2, 2016 | accessdate=April 7, 2016 | author=Botelho, Greg}}</ref> Early in the 2017 legislative session Republican Sen. Lance Russell refiled the bathroom bill but on January 30 he withdrew the bill because of GOP Gov. [[Dennis Daugaard]] again promised a veto.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.startribune.com/south-dakota-s-transgender-locker-room-bill-withdrawn/412276933/ | title=South Dakota's transgender locker room bill scuttled | work=Associated Press | date=January 31, 2017 | accessdate=March 10, 2017 | author=Nord, James}}</ref>
====Tennessee==== On April 6, 2016, the [[Tennessee]] House Education Administration and Planning Committee, which is part of the [[Tennessee House of Representatives]], approved a bathroom bill that would apply to public schools and colleges in the state and would require students to use a restroom that corresponds with their sex as identified at birth.<ref name=vox/><ref name=TennPulls/> Before the bill could proceed further, the house sponsor of the bill decided to delay its consideration for a year to allow for further investigation, citing concerns that it could interfere with Title IX funding.<ref name=TennPulls>{{Cite web |first=Joel |last=Ebert |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2016/04/18/transgender-bathroom-bill-sponsor-pulls-proposal-until-next-year/83192670/ |title=Transgender bathroom bill dead for year |newspaper=[[The Tennessean]] |date=April 18, 2016 |access-date=July 18, 2016}}</ref> In 2017, the bill was re-introduced, but died in the Senate Education Committee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tennessee transgender bathroom bill fails in Senate panel|url=http://wreg.com/2017/03/22/tennessee-transgender-bathroom-bill-fails-in-senate-panel/|accessdate=October 9, 2017|agency=AP|publisher=News Channel 3|date=March 22, 2017}}</ref>
====Texas==== [[File:Texans protest the Trans bathroom bill outside the senate committee hearing on SB-6 (32468713294).jpg|thumb|right|Public opposition to SB6 in the State Capitol]] A bill introduced to the Texas House of Representatives in March 2015 proposed that any student who encountered another student who does not identify with their "biological sex" in a shared restroom could be awarded $2,000 in damage reparations for "mental anguish." The school itself would also be liable for failing to take action against known transgender students using their gender identified restroom.<ref name="Texas transphobic legislature proposal news">{{cite news|last1=Brydumm|first1=Sunnivie|title=Texas Doubles Down on Transphobic Legislation, Adding $2,000 Fine for 'Wrong' Bathroom Use|url=http://www.advocate.com/politics/transgender/2015/03/10/texas-doubles-down-transphobic-legislation-adding-2000-fine-wrong-ba|publisher=Advocate|date=March 10, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=H.B. No. 2801|url=http://www.legis.state.tx.us/tlodocs/84R/billtext/pdf/HB02801I.pdf#navpanes=0}}</ref>
Another bill, introduced to the Texas House in February 2015, suggested that anyone over the age of 13 years found to be in a public restroom of a gender not their own should be charged with a Class A misdemeanor, spend up to a year in jail, and face a $4000 fine.<ref name="Advocate Texas Bill 1748">{{cite news|last1=Kellaway|first1=Mitch|title=Texas Bill Would Jail Those Whose Chromosomes Don't Match the Restroom They're Using|url=http://www.advocate.com/politics/transgender/2015/02/24/texas-bill-would-jail-those-whose-chromosomes-dont-match-restroom-th|publisher=Advocate|date=February 24, 2015}}</ref> Under this proposed bill, building managers who repeatedly and knowingly allow transgender individuals to use the facility of their gender identity would also face a fine of up to $10,000.<ref name="H.B. 1748 Texas">{{cite web|title=H.B 1748|url=http://www.legis.state.tx.us/tlodocs/84R/billtext/html/HB01748I.htm|publisher=Texas Legislature}}</ref>
Several bills were filed in both the regular legislative session and first special session of the [[Texas Legislature]] in 2017. Sponsored by State Sen. Lois Kolkhorst and championed by Lt. Governor [[Dan Patrick (politician)|Dan Patrick,]] the [[Texas Senate]] passed SB6 in the regular session and SB3 in the Special Session by a vote of 21-10 largely along party lines (Senator [[Eddie Lucio Jr.]] was the only Democrat to vote in favor of each bill). Neither bill went to the House floor for a vote (although SB6 received a hearing by the House's State Affairs committee). SB6 would have limited bathroom access based on the sex listed on one's birth certificate while SB3 would have allowed an individual to use the restroom listed on several state IDs as well (e.g. driver's license or [[Concealed carry in the United States|concealed carry license]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/texas-legislature/2017/03/14/bathroom-bill-gets-first-thumbs-texas-senate |title=Bathroom of 'biological sex' bill passes Texas Senate |date=March 14, 2017 |work=Dallas Morning News |accessdate=March 15, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.texastribune.org/2017/07/25/texas-senate-votes-advance-bathroom-bill-again/ |title=Texas Senate Votes Again To Advance "Bathroom Bill" |date=July 25, 2017 |work=The Texas Tribune |accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref>
The [[Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives|Speaker]] of the Texas House [[Joe Straus]] voiced his opposition to the bills, citing the economic impact that North Carolina saw while HB2 was law. He was also quoted by a [[The New Yorker|''New Yorker'']] article as saying, "I'm disgusted by all this. Tell the lieutenant governor I don't want the suicide of a single Texan on my hands."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/07/10/americas-future-is-texas |title=America's Future Is Texas |date=July 10, 2017 |work=New Yorker |accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref>
In September 2018, Kolkhorst indicated that she would try again to pass similar legislation.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Smith |first1=Gwendolyn |title=GOP reboots for another round of anti-trans bathroom bills in TX |url=https://www.lgbtqnation.com/2018/09/gop-reboots-another-round-anti-trans-bathroom-bills-tx/ |accessdate=14 September 2018 |publisher=LGBTQ Nation |date=13 September 2018}}</ref>
====Vermont==== On May 11, 2018, Vermont Gov. Phil Scott signed a bill requiring all single-user public restrooms to be gender-neutral.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ring|first1=Trudy|title=Vermont Gov. Signs Gender-Neutral Restroom Bill|url=https://www.advocate.com/politics/2018/5/14/vermont-gov-signs-gender-neutral-restroom-bill|accessdate=17 May 2018|publisher=The Advocate|date=14 May 2018}}</ref>
====Virginia==== In 2016, Del. [[Mark Cole (politician)|Mark Cole]] sponsored House Bill 663, a bathroom bill restricting public restroom use according to a person's "anatomical sex", defined as "the physical condition of being male or female, which is determined by a person's anatomy", with violators liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $50. HB663 was introduced on January 11, 2016 and died in committee in February 2016.<ref name=HB663-2016>{{cite web |url=http://lis.virginia.gov/cgi-bin/legp604.exe?161+sum+HB663 |title=HB 663 Restroom facilities; use of facilities in public buildings or schools |author=Cole, Mark L. |date=11 January 2016 |publisher=Virginia General Assembly |accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> It was widely reported that HB663 would require adults to inspect the genitals of children before they were allowed to enter the appropriate facilities, but this was dismissed by ''[[Snopes]]'' as a misleading interpretation of the bill's text,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.snopes.com/mark-cole-controversy/ |title=Cole's Law |author=LaCapria, Kim |date=13 January 2016 |publisher=Snopes |accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> which states that administrators "shall develop and implement policies that require every restroom ... that is designated for use by a specific gender to solely be used by individuals whose anatomical sex matches such gender designation."<ref name=HB663-2016 /> Cole sponsored House Bill 781 one day later on January 12, 2016, which used the same wording but substituted "biological sex" for "anatomical sex". The use of "biological sex" allowed for an update via amended birth certificate. HB781 also died in committee in February.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lis.virginia.gov/cgi-bin/legp604.exe?161+sum+HB781 |title=HB 781 Restroom facilities; use of facilities in public buildings or schools, definition of biological sex |author=Cole, Mark L. |date=11 January 2016 |publisher=Virginia General Assembly |accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
In early 2017, HB1612, proposed by Republican [[Bob Marshall (Virginia politician)|Bob Marshall]] would use the "born sex" to define which restroom, changing facility, or private area in government buildings was permitted for a given individual.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Koma|first1=Alex|title=Del. Bob Marshall introduces transgender "bathroom bill"|url=http://www.insidenova.com/headlines/del-bob-marshall-introduces-transgender-bathroom-bill/article_8fb849cc-d2c3-11e6-a342-0b2dac3505fd.html|website=InsideNOVA|publisher=Northern Virginia Media Services|accessdate=January 20, 2017|date=January 4, 2017}}</ref> In HB1612, it also stated that individuals that did not use the bathroom of their born sex would be subject to civil action. Additionally, HB1612 required school principals to inform the parents of a child if the child did not wish to identify as their born sex. The bill was killed in subcommittee on January 19, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Subcommittee kills Virginia transgender "bathroom bill"|url=http://wtkr.com/2017/01/19/virginia-bathroom-bill-struck-dead-at-at-the-house-of-delegates-subcommittee-meeting/|website=[[WTKR]]|accessdate=January 20, 2017|date=January 19, 2017}}</ref>
====Washington==== In early 2015, SB 6548, which would prevent transgender individuals from using the bathroom associated with the gender with which they identify was introduced in the senate but failed to pass.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://app.leg.wa.gov/billsummary?BillNumber=6548&Year=2015|title=SB 6548 - 2015-16|publisher=Washington State Legislature}}</ref> In December 2015, Washington State's Human Rights Commission enacted a rule that allowed transgender individuals to use bathrooms conforming with their gender identities. Early in 2016, a bill to overturn the ruling (SB 6443) was voted on in the state Senate, and defeated by a margin of 25-24.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.advocate.com/politics/2016/2/11/transphobic-bathroom-bill-dies-washington-state|title=Transphobic Bathroom Bill Dies in Washington State|date=February 11, 2016|access-date=January 6, 2017}}</ref> An attempt to put a state voter initiative on the November 2016 ballot, I-1515, failed to reach the number of signatures necessary to appear on the ballot.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/politics/article/I-1515-the-bathroom-initiative-fails-to-make-8346927.php|title=I-1515, the 'bathroom initiative,' fails to make November ballot|newspaper=seattlepi.com|access-date=January 6, 2017}}</ref> On December 5, 2016, a new bill, HB 1011 was pre-filed in the Washington State House. This bill would prevent transgender individuals from using a bathroom of their gender identity unless they have had sex-reassignment surgery, and would prevent local municipalities from enacting ordinances contradicting the directive.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lgbtqnation.com/2016/12/washington-state-gop-lawmakers-introduce-anti-transgender-bathroom-bill/|title=Washington State GOP lawmakers introduce anti-transgender bathroom bill|newspaper=LGBTQ Nation|access-date=January 6, 2017}}</ref>
====Wisconsin==== In November 2015, [[Wisconsin]] held a hearing on a bathroom bill to require public schoolchildren to use facilities that match the sex they were assigned at birth. According to critics, the bill would also violate the federal government's [[Office for Civil Rights]]'s 2014 statement that federal nondiscrimination law covered gender identity. The following month, the bill was revised to allow public schools to offer gender-neutral bathrooms.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.twincities.com/2015/12/16/bill-revised-to-allow-gender-neutral-bathrooms-in-wisconsin-schools/ | title=Bill revised to allow gender-neutral bathrooms in Wisconsin schools | work=St. Paul Pioneer Press | date=December 16, 2015 | accessdate=April 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://host.madison.com/wsj/news/local/govt-and-politics/if-passed-gop-transgender-bathroom-bill-would-be-first-in/article_d0190e46-b6b1-595b-a1c8-4a5cd52860f2.html | title=If passed, GOP transgender bathroom bill would be first in the nation | work=Madison.com | date=November 20, 2015 | accessdate=April 7, 2016 | author=Beck, Molly}}</ref>

{{SCCInfoBox | case-name=Beals v Saldanha| heard-date=February 20, 2003| decided-date=December 18, 2003| full-case-name=Geoffrey Saldanha, Leueen Saldanha and Dominic Thivy v. Frederick H. Beals III and Patricia A. Beals| citations= [2003] 3 S.C.R. 416, 2003 SCC 72 | history=Judgment for Beals in the [[Court of Appeal for Ontario]].| docket=28829| ruling= Appeal dismissed.| ratio= The "[[real and substantial connection]]" test should apply to conflict of law issues related to recognition and enforcement of non-Canadian judgments.| SCC=2002-2003| Majority=Major J. (paras. 1-80)| JoinMajority=McLachlin C.J. and Gonthier, Bastarache, Arbour and Deschamps JJ.| Dissent=Binnie J. (paras. 81-131)| JoinDissent=Iacobucci J.| Dissent2=LeBel J. (paras. 132-267)| }} '''''Beals v Saldanha''''', [2003] 3 S.C.R. 416, 2003 SCC 72 is a leading [[Supreme Court of Canada]] decision on the [[conflict of laws]], where the Court established the requirements to enforce foreign judgments in Canada. The Court held that foreign judgments were enforceable in Canada where there was a "[[real and substantial connection]]" between the foreign jurisdiction and the subject matter giving rise to the claim.
==Background== Geoffrey and Leueen Saldanha and Dominic Thivy were residents of Ontario and sold lots they owned in Florida to Frederick and Patricia Beals. Beals brought an action against Saldanha and Thivy when it was discovered that the defendants did not actually own the property they sold. A defence was filed with the Court but did nothing afterwards and defaulted. A jury awarded Beals $260,000 in damages.
Thivy and Saldanha were informed by a lawyer in Ontario that the judgment could not be enforced and so they did nothing.
Soon Beals brought an action in Ontario to enforce the judgment, which had grown to $800,000 with interest.
At trial the judgment was denied on the basis that the damages had been improperly assessed. On Appeal the Court allowed the foreign judgment.
The issue before the Supreme Court was whether a judgment issued by a Court in Florida could be enforced in Ontario, and whether the defendant could seek refuge under [[Section Seven of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|section 7]] of the ''[[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|Charter]]''.
==Reasons of the court== In a six to three decision, the Court found that the judgment was enforceable. The Court applied the "real and substantial connection" test from the earlier decision of ''[[Morguard v. De Savoye]]'' to the international context. The test requires the Court to consider whether the subject-matter of the suit or the person involved had a "real and substantial" connection with the country. The Court noted, however, that judgments with sufficient connection will not be enforced if they are contrary to Canadian public policy, contrary to natural justice, or obtained through fraud.
==Dissent== Justice LeBel, in dissent, argued for a strengthening of the available defences. He noted that the result in this case was overly harsh and unfair by imposing an 800,000 judgment on an 8,000 property due to essentially bad luck.<ref>para. 132</ref> He proposed that the real and substantial connection test be modified in the international context to reflect the added hardships imposed on litigating in a foreign country.<ref>para. 134</ref>
In his view, the defences of fraud and natural justice should be broadened in international matters<ref>para.217-218</ref> and an additional residual category should be allowed for injustices that do not easily fit into the main categories using what lower court called a "judicial sniff test".
LeBel pointed to a number of examples such as the Hague Conference on foreign judgments had proposed to grant domestic judges to lower foreign punitive damages.<ref>para. 220</ref> and the Loewen case, where a Mississippi jury awarded 500 million in damages against a BC company for anti-competitive practices.<ref>para. 228</ref>

{{Infobox award | name = Burton Awards | image = | imagesize = | caption = | description = Outstanding accomplishments in law | presenter = Burton Foundation, In association with the [[Library of Congress]] and Co-sponsored by the American Bar Association | country = United States | year = 1999-present | website = http://www.burtonawards.com/ }}
The '''Burton Awards''' program is run in association with the Library of Congress and co-sponsored by the American Bar Association. The awards are generally selected by professors from [[Harvard Law School]], Yale Law School, Stanford Law School, and Columbia Law School, among others. Judge [[Richard Posner]] of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit|Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals]], Judge [[Alex Kozinski]] of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]], and Judge [[Carol Corrigan]] of the [[Supreme Court of California]] are honorary members on the board of directors. In addition, U.S. Senators Cornyn, Bennett, Crapo, and Casey are also honorary members.
Each year, an elite number of Legal Writing Award winners are chosen from partners at the largest law firms in the nation, as well as Law School Award winners. Other Burton Awards are presented annually which include the "Book of the Year Award," and "Outstanding Contributions to Legal Writing Education Award." Even awards to lawyers in the military are given at the event.
The award ceremonies are annually held at the Library of Congress in Washington D.C. Prominent officials who have been guest speakers at the event have included Supreme Court Justice Stephen Breyer, Justice [[Antonin Scalia]], [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg|Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg]], Justice [[Sonia Sotomayor]] and Justice John Paul Stevens (''retired''). In the past, other well-known dignitaries have participated in the program including Tom Brokaw, Bob Schieffer, Tim Russert, Chris Matthews, George Will and master of ceremonies, Bill Press. The entertainers have included Jay Leno, Kristen Chenoweth, Bernadette Peters, and Vanessa Williams.
== Awards ==
* '''Distinguished Writing Awards'''- ''Category of Law Firms'' [http://www.burtonawards.com/awards.html] Presented to the best law firm authors of articles dealing with legal issues published in the previous year. * '''Distinguished Writing Awards'''- ''Category of Law Schools'' [http://www.burtonawards.com/awards-student.html] Presented to the best law school authors of articles dealing with legal issues published in the previous year. * '''Distinguished Public Service in the Military''' - [http://www.burtonawards.com/awards-legal.html] Presented to the finest lawyers in the military. * '''Outstanding Contributions to Legal Writing Education Award''' - [http://www.burtonawards.com/awards-legal.html] Presented for outstanding contributions to the education of new lawyers in the field of legal analysis, research and writing, whether through teaching, program design, program support, innovative thinking or writing. * '''The Legends in Law Awards''' - * ''Category of General Counsel'' [http://www.burtonawards.com/legends-award.html] This selection is made on the following criteria: reputation in both the legal profession and as a proven authority in a specialized area of law; background and experience; complexity and scope of matters handled; global or national importance of issues confronted and proven and exemplary leadership in law. * '''Book of the Year Award''' - Presented to the authors of the most outstanding book in the profession of law. * '''The Outstanding Journalist in Law''' - Presented for a lifetime of achievement and accomplishment reporting on legal issues, cases or the profession.<ref>[http://www.burtonawards.com/awards.html]</ref>
== Honorary Board of Directors ==
The honorary and distinguished members of the Burton Awards Board of Directors include the following leaders in law: Former Chief Judge Richard Posner, 7th Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals; U.S. Senator John Cornyn; U.S. Senator Robert P. Casey, Jr.; U.S. Senator Mike Crapo; U.S. Senator Michael F. Bennet; Supreme Court; U.S. Senator Christopher Van Hollen: Justice Carol Corrigan of California; Yabo Lin, Partner, Sidley Austin LLP; Jane Sullivan Roberts, Partner, Major, Lindsey & Africa; Lisa Rickard, President, U.S. Chamber Institute for Legal Reform; Thomas L. Sager, Partner, Ballard Spahr LLP; Les Parrette, Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Compliance Officer, Novelis Inc.; James M. Rishwain, Jr., Chairman of Emeritus, Pillsbury Winthrop LLP; Betty Whelchel, Head of Public Policy & Regulatory Affairs, BNP Paribas SA; and Stephen R. Mysliwiec, Partner, DLA Piper LLP.

{{Admiralty law}} {{refimprove|date=July 2010}} A '''contract of carriage''' is a [[contract]] between a carrier of goods or passengers and the [[consignor]], [[consignee]] or [[passenger]]. Contracts of carriage typically define the rights, duties and liabilities of parties to the contract, addressing topics such as [[act of God|acts of God]] and including clauses such as ''[[force majeure]]''. Among [[common carrier]]s, they are usually evidenced by standard terms and conditions printed on the reverse of a ticket or carriage document.
==Air travel== In July 2010, it became widely public that [[Southwest Airlines]] had classified mechanical difficulties as an [[act of God]] in their contract of carriage, expanding the definition formerly shared with Delta, American, Continental and United.<ref>{{cite web| title= Southwest: Breakdown is now an act of God | publisher= [[Arizona Daily Star]] | date= July 24, 2010 | url= http://azstarnet.com/news/local/article_5bc41260-e1ee-57fb-8f68-fe716e9f5bad.html| accessdate= 2010-07-27}}</ref> This was later clarified by the airline as mechanical difficulties beyond the airline's control, as for instance the failure of the air traffic control system, or fuel delivery systems operated by airports.
===Involuntary denial of boarding===
The rate of passengers who are involuntarily denied boarding is around 1 in 10,000 and has been falling for the 25 years between 1990 and 2015.<ref> [https://www.rita.dot.gov/bts/sites/rita.dot.gov.bts/files/publications/national_transportation_statistics/html/table_01_64.html Passengers Boarded and Denied Boarding by the Largest U.S. Air Carriers] - US DOT</ref>
According to aviation analyst Henry Harteveldt, the airline's Contract of carriage<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.airfarewatchdog.com/pages/3802676/airline-contracts-of-carriage/ |title=Airline Contracts of Carriage |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=Airfare Watchdog |publisher=Smarter Travel Media LLC |access-date=April 12, 2017 |quote=What are your rights if an airline delays or cancels your flight, or loses your bags? What are the airlines' rules and regulations}}</ref> favors the company, not the passenger. Involuntary denial of boarding is not uncommon<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2017/04/daily-chart-6 |title=United bumps more passengers than any other large American airline |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=April 11, 2017 |website=The Economist |publisher=The Economist |access-date=April 12, 2017}}</ref> but removal after boarding because the seat is needed by others is "exceedingly rare". Nonetheless, an airline has a right to do so based on the contract, in his view. "Remember, it is their aircraft and their seat — you're just renting it to get from point A to point B," Harteveldt told [[Business Insider]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/how-airline-choose-who-kick-off-flight-united-american-delta-2017-4 |title=How airlines like United choose who to kick off a flight |last=Zhang |first=Benjamin |date=April 10, 2017 |website=Business Insider |publisher=Business Insider Inc. |access-date=April 12, 2017}}</ref>
==Rail travel== Cross-border European railway tickets are covered by the [[CIV (rail travel)|CIV]] conditions of sale.
